instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
Hi,

Got <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with liquid damage on UA900 area.


Replaced:

UA900
CA902
CA903
CA901
CA900
CA905
RA900

They were fucked.


Now getting 20V from the port but the machine doesnt start.


Measurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V (shorted to ground. Injecting 5V nothing warming)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 0.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0.4V going down.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.4V and going down



Any suggestion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
Never inject voltage before checking if NO high-side MOSFET is shorted...

Which is the exact value at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V, in respect with ground?
Post it in diode mode, red probe to ground.
If is very low, then check exact value on 200 ohms scale.

"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 0.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0.4V going down."
These require <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> presence first.

<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> is generated by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message: Thanks. Will check it ok the morning and back with result

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
In Diode mode is very low: 0.002

Resistance to ground 1,2 Ohms

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0.4V going down."

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
Now check in 200 ohm scale if any big coil (from secondary power supplies) has the same value to ground.
If yes, confirm to get 000 between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and that coil.
It will mean corresponding high-side MOSFET is shorted.
If no such problem found, then you can inject voltage...

BTW, remember when check diode mode (or ohm scale) on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, both charger and battery must be unplugged.
If not, you will get false short indication.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message: Yep make sure charger unplugged. Remove F7000/1, and see if your short is on pin 1 or pin 2. If pin 1, inject 5 volts and see what heats up. If pin 2, start low around 1 volt and see what heats up. In a liquid damage case, I would not be surprised if pin 2 would be shorted through the CPU/high side mosfet as 2informaticos mentioned.

It will mean corresponding high-side MOSFET is shorted.
If no such problem found, then you can inject voltage...

BTW, remember when check diode mode (or ohm scale) on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, both charger and battery must be unplugged.
If not, you will get false short indication.[/QUOTE]

Thanks 2informaticos. 


Got 2.5 Ohms on LA640, L7231, 3.5Ohms on L7221/11 and 6 Ohms on L7420/10. Seems no coil is shorted. 

P:S. yep, all unpluged.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message: injecting through pin 2 seems be GPU. Getting warm and producing electric sound. Dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
If the reading on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is lower than any coil, then is no shorted high-side MOSFET.
Should be a capacitor, or some IC directly connected to the main power rail.
However is no reason for GPU to overheat when inject, if high-side MOSFET of its power supply is not shorted.
Be sure you took correct readings from all coils...

BTW, don't quote an entire post; just select the related words.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message: If the GPU is getting warm, that's not good. Inspect closely by it for caps that may be heating. If the only thing getting warm is the GPU, this is done

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message: I think GPU is dead. The only thing is getting warm is GPU.

threads.message:
Check resistance (200 ohm scale) between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and LA900:
Do the same for LA640/50.
And then compare with resistance to ground on all these points...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message: On LA900 1.645 kohms, LA640/50 2.9 to ppbus and 2.2 ohms to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
I forgot about LA300, is on GPU too.
If don't get lower value between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and any of GPU power supply, then is very strange to get hot GPU...
